name: Gaussian correlation inequality
rephrased: For two symmetric, convex sets in a multidimensional Gaussian (normal) space, the probability that a randomly sampled point falls into both sets is at least the product of the probabilities of falling into each set individually.
implication_form: If A and B are symmetric convex sets in R^n with respect to the standard Gaussian measure, then the probability of the intersection of A and B is at least the product of the probabilities of A and B individually.
posed_by: Vladimir Dubcovskiy and others (the conjecture was proposed in different forms by various mathematicians starting in the 1970s)
explained: The Gaussian Correlation Inequality (GCI), now a theorem, states that for any two symmetric convex sets A and B in R^n, and for two independent standard Gaussian random vectors X and Y (each with mean 0 and covariance identity), the probability that both X ∈ A and Y ∈ B is at least the product of the individual probabilities P(X ∈ A) * P(Y ∈ B). In other words, the events {X ∈ A} and {Y ∈ B} are positively correlated. This inequality formalizes the intuition that events defined by symmetric convex regions in a Gaussian space tend to overlap more than random subsets would suggest.
related_conjectures: Hypercube Conjecture (a special case where the ambient space is a hypercube)
